Authors:
Ryo Sugawara, Kozue Sotome, Nitaro Maekawa, Akira Nakagiri,
Naoki Endo
Title: Taxonomic reconstruction of Hydnum species in Japan.
Keywords:
Cantharellales; cryptic species; East Asian species;
ectomycorrhizal fungi; ITS; mating test; tef1; 9 new taxa.
Abstract:
Hydnum (Hydnaceae, Basidiomycota) shows an endemic species
diversity in East Asia but few comprehensive taxonomic studies have been
done yet. In this study, the taxonomy of Hydnum species in Japan was
evaluated morphologically, ecologically, phylogenetically, and
biologically. Total 186 Japanese Hydnum specimens were employed for
morphological observation. Phylogenetic trees were constructed using
sequence data of nuc rDNA internal transcribed spacer ITS1-5.8S-ITS2
(ITS) region and translation elongation factor 1-Î± (tef1) gene. The
intra- and interspecific mating tests using 78 monokaryotic strains of
13 species did not conflict with species delimitation inferred from
their ITS and tef1 phylogenetic relationships. This study rigorously
identified a total of 16 species from Japan, thus we provided their
detailed morphological descriptions. Among them, nine species, i.e., H.
alboluteum, H. albopallidum, H. pinicola, H. itachiharitake, H.
minospororufescens, H. orientalbidum, H. subberkeleyanum, H. tomaense,
H. tottoriense are here with described as new species. Three species,
i.e., H. boreorepandum, H. mulsicolor, and H. umbilicatum are new to
Japan. Remaining three species, i.e., H. cremeoalbum, H. minus and H.
repando-orientale, previously reported from Japan, are re-described with
the data from newly collected materials. These results suggest that the
diversity of Hydnum species is high even in the limited region in East
Asia.
